svg:text.svg:tspan: Section Six — Improving and Marking Sample Answers
Mark the Answer
of the birth, caesurae in the phrase “We want, we shouted, / To be two, to be ourselves.” slow
the pace of the poem and hint at the separation being an exhausting struggle — it’s as though
the speaker has to keep pausing for breath. Although the struggle of Weir’s speaker is different,
it is shown in a similar way. When describing her son as a child in the second stanza, most
of the lines ﬂow freely into the next, hinting that the speaker is caught up in her thoughts and
doesn’t want to stop thinking of her son as he was. However, caesurae appear in the middle of
some lines, such as in “All my words / ﬂattened, rolled, turned into felt”. Again, this slows the
pace of the poem and seems to indicate that the speaker is pausing to regain her composure,
emphasising the mental strain that the separation has caused.
Both poems also use the colour red to symbolise the strong emotions that separation
causes. Clarke’s “Red rope of love” not only evokes the blood and pain that is inherent in
childbirth, but as the colour red can also symbolise passion and love, it emphasises the strong
bond between the mother and daughter. This mixture of pain and love reinforces the tension
that’s caused by the pair’s separation — they both want to be more independent, but still have
a strong familial bond. In Weir’s poem, the description of the poppy’s petals as “spasms of
paper red” presents a similar feeling of pain to the reader, as the words of “spasms” and “red”
evoke images of bloody soldiers dying on a battleﬁeld. Using this language of pain to describe
a symbol associated with Remembrance Day, a day where people commemorate those who gave
their lives in the armed forces, reminds the reader that it’s not just the mother in the poem who
experiences this pain, but also every individual who has lost someone due to war.
Clarke and Weir’s use of sensory language reinforces how separation is presented in each
poem. At the end of ‘Catrin’, the “old rope” that connects the mother and daughter returns,
tying the two stanzas of the poem together in the process. Rather than them ﬁghting over the
rope, this time it is described as “Tightening” about the speaker’s “life”. Despite the separation
caused by the daughter becoming more independent, the word “Tightening” appeals to the
sense of touch to create a strong feeling of constriction, and highlights how the speaker still
feels that she lacks freedom and separation. ‘Poppies’ contrasts with this, instead describing
how the mother and her son used to “play” by grazing their noses together. Here, the face-to-
face intimacy and use of “play” shows that the sense of touch is loving and comforting. In both
cases, the sense of touch is used to reﬂect the desire of each speaker, with Clarke’s speaker
seeking a sense of separation and Weir’s speaker desperately wanting to be reunited with her son.
Comparing the poems side by side adds a sense of poignancy, as after reading about the intense
pain that separation has caused the mother in ‘Poppies’, the reader might believe that Clarke’s
speaker perhaps doesn’t fully appreciate the close relationship she has with her daughter.
Both ‘Catrin’ and ‘Poppies’ focus on different feelings of separation. Clarke focuses on the
desire for separation and independence within a mother-child relationship, whereas Weir focuses
on the heartache that is caused by losing this bond. Despite this, both poems present separation
in a similar way. They both use vivid language to show how separation is associated with pain,
and both present separation as having a strong effect on individuals by demonstrating how it can
inﬂuence how people think and feel.
